questions.text: A child presents with lesions on the trunk and inner thigh as shown in the figure. It initially started as a macule and later developed into nodules, few of which have central umbilication. Which of the following will be seen in histopathology?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Henderson Paterson bodies The given clinical scenario and histological image are diagnostic of molluscum contagiosum lesions, which show intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies, called Henderson-Patterson bodies or molluscum bodies .

Highyeild:

MOLLUSCUM CONTAGIOSUM INFECTION: Infection is usually spread by direct contact, particularly among children and young adults. Multiple lesions occur on the skin and mucous membranes, with a predilection for the trunk and anogenital areas . Individual lesions are firm, pruritic, pink to skin-colored umbilicated papules . A curd-like material can be expressed from the central umbilication. Smearing this material onto a glass slide and Giemsa staining shows diagnostic molluscum bodies , which are ellipsoid, homogeneous, cytoplasmic inclusions that are found in the cells of the stratum granulosum and the stratum corneum and are up to 35 um in size. Viral inclusion bodies Intracytoplasmic Henderson-Peterson bodies (Molluscum Contagiosum) Negri bodies (Rabies) Guarnieri bodies (Small pox) Paschen bodies (Small pox) Bollinger bodies (Fowl pox) Borrel bodies (Fowl pox) Intranuclear Acidophilic Cowdry type A Varicella zoster virus Herpes simplex virus Yellow fever virus Cowdry type B Polio virus Basophilic Cowdry type B Adeno virus Cytomegalo virus

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A : Donovan bodies are seen in donovanosis, caused by Klebsiella granulomatis. Donovan bodies are minute, encapsulated coccobacilli in macrophages, which can be demonstrated in Giemsa-stained smears of the exudate. Option B : Multinucleated giant cells (called Tzanck cells) are seen in herpes simplex virus infections. They are formed when individual epidermal cells containing viral inclusions fuse to produce giant cells. These can be demonstrated by the diagnostic Tzanck test Option D : Koilocytes are characteristically seen in HPV infections. Koilocytes are lining cells that have perinuclear cytoplasmic vacuolization.

questions.text: A 10 year old boy noticed the passage of a white thread like worm in stool. Microscopic examination of the anterior end of the worm is shown in the figure. The segments of the worm had breadth greater than length. Which of the following eggs would be likely seen in stool? Choose the correct answer from below given options:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1 Presence of segments suggest the parasite as cestode . Image shows it to be armed and broad segments suggesting it to be H nana. Diagnosis is usually made by looking at typical non bile stained eggs with 3 pairs of Hooksett, polar filaments and yolk granules.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - B-Egg of H. nana. C- Egg of Ascaris lumbricoides D- Egg of Enterobius vermicularis

questions.text: Which of the following viruses exhibits genetic reassortment similar to that of the influenza virus?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1 1 –is having a segmented genome & hence can show reassortment. Genetic Reassortment is the process by which influenza viruses swap gene segments. This genetic exchange is possible due to the segmented nature of the viral genome Option A Rotavirus Hence option 1 is the correct answer Option B Adenovirus is not segmented Hence option B is not correct option Option C Ebola virus not segmented Hence option C is not correct option Option D Rabies virus Not segmented Hence option D is not correct option

Highyeild:

Segmented viruses are (BORA) Arenaviridae Bunyavirales Orthomyxoviridae (influenza) Rotavirus

questions.text: Which of the following cytokines are not Involved in a TH2 response?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

IL 12 Cytokines are proteins produced by many cell types (principally activated lymphocytes, macrophages, and dendritic cells, but also endothelial, epithelial, and connective tissue cells) that mediate and regulate immune and inflammatory reactions. Three subsets of CD4- T cells secrete different types of cytokines and elicit different types of inflammation. TH1 cells - activate macrophages by the classical pathway by secreting IFNy TH2 cells - recruit and activate eosinophils and are responsible for the alternative pathway of macrophage activation by secreting IL4, IL5, and IL13 IL4 acts on B cells to stimulate class switching to lgE and promotes the development of additional TH2 cells. IL5 is involved in the development and activation of eosinophils, which are essential effectors of type I hypersensitivity (discussed later). IL13 enhances IgE production and acts on epithelial cells to stimulate mucus secretion TH17 cells secrete IL17 and other cytokines responsible for neutrophils and monocyte recruitment. Cytokines produced IFN-Y IL-4, IL-5, IL-13 IL-17, IL-22 Cytokines that induce this subset IFN-7, IL-12 IL-4 TGF-B, IL-6, IL-1, IL-23 Immunological reactions triggered Macrophage activation Stimulation of IgE production, activation of mast cells and eosinophils Recruitment of neutrophils, monocytes Host defense against Intracellular microbes Helminthic parasites Extracellular bacteria, fungi Role in disease Immune-mediated chronic inflammatory diseases (often autoimmune Allergies Immune-mediated chronic inflammatory diseases (often autoimmune

questions.text: Which of the following given below can destroy spores? Ethylene oxide Glutaraldehyde Pasteurization Orthophthaldehyde Choose the correct answer from below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1,2,4 Methods of sterilisation and disinfection Spectrum Uses 1. Heat Hot air oven All Glasswares, sterilizing powders, oils, swabs and dressings Autoclaving All Linen, surgical instruments, laboratory ware, media and pharmaceutical products Boiling Most pathogens, some spores Metal tools, rubber or plastic equipment, cloth Pasteurization Vegetative bacteria Beverages, plastic hospital equipment 2. Ethylene oxide gas All Heat-sensitive equipment like heart-lung machines, artificial valves, fabrics, respirators, cardiac catheters, books 3. Radiation UV All Limited value due to poor penetration, can be used for plastic syringes, catheters, and laboratory cabinets lonising All Surgical supplies, food 4. Chemicals Alcohol Skin disinfection, hand washing Hydrogen peroxide Vegetative bacteria, viruses some spores High-level disinfectant, antiseptic for wounds and discharging ulcers Chlorine Viruses, vegetative bacteria, fungi To disinfect water lodophors Viruses, vegetative bacteria, fungi, lethal to spore-bearing organisms Skin disinfection, disinfect blood culture bottles and medical equipment Crude phenol Gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria, but only slowly effective against spores and acid- fast bacteria Disinfection of faeces, mopping floors and cleaning drains. 5. Glutaraldehyde All Endoscopes, bronchoscopes 6. Quarternary ammonium compounds Most bacteria, fungi, lipophilic viruses General cleaning

questions.text: An HIV positive male with a CD4 count of 145/cumm reports to the OPD with complaints of severe watery diarrhoea for the last 3 days. Acid fast stain of a stool sample demonstrated acid fast round the size of 4-6 microns. Which of the following is the likely etiology of the symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cryptosporidium Hominis Cryptosporidiosis is caused by various species of the protozoan parasite Cryptosporidium, which infects the small bowel mucosa, and, if symptomatic, the infection typically causes diarrhoea. Advanced immunosuppression—typically CD4 T lymphocyte cell (CD4) counts <100 cells/mm3—is associated with the greatest risk for prolonged, severe, or extraintestinal cryptosporidiosis Diagnosis of cryptosporidiosis was traditionally made by microscopic identification of the oocysts in stool with acid-fast staining or direct immunofluorescence, which offers higher sensitivity. Concentration methods (e.g., formalin-ethyl acetate) may facilitate diagnosis of cryptosporidiosis. Isospora belli : Cystoisospora belli, previously known as Isospora belli, is a parasite that causes an intestinal disease known as Cysto isosporiasis Cyclospora is a genus of apicomplexan parasites. It includes the species Cyclospora cayetanensis, the causative agent of cyclosporiasis. Members of Cyclospora are characterized as having oocysts with two sporocysts, each containing two sporozoites

Extraedge:

Oocysts in clinical specimens may be difficult to identify with out special staining. Modified acid-fast (partial acid-fast) stains are recommended for identifying these organisms. This test detects coccidian parasites (Cryptosporidium, Cyclospora, or Isospora belli) in stool. It is used to evaluate chronic diarrhea.

Table:

Coccidia Characterized by thick-walled oocysts excreted in feces In Humans Cryptosporidium Isospora Cyclospora Toxoplasma Sarcocystis

questions.text: Microscopy technique that can be utilised to produce high- contrast images of transparent specimens, such as living cells, is-
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Phase Contrast Microscopy Phase-contrast microscopy is an optical microscopy technique that converts phase shifts in l ight passing through a transparent specimen to brightness changes in the image. Phase shifts themselves are invisible, but become visible when shown as brightness variations

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Dark-field microscopy describes microscopy methods, in both light and electron microscopy, which exclude the unscattered beam from the image Option: C. Polarised light microscopy can mean any of a number of optical microscopy techniques involving polarised light. Simple techniques include illumination of the sample with polarised light. Option: D. Electron Microscopes (EMs) function like their optical counterparts except that they use a focused beam of electrons instead of photons to "image" the specimen and gain information as to its structure and composition.

questions.text: A microbiologist performed a tissue gram stain and found thin, filamentous bacteria shown in the figure. What other staining technique should be done to confirm the diagnosis as Nocardia?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Modified Acid Fast Stain Nocardia is typically weakly acid-fast after traditional carbol-fuchsin staining and positive on modified acid-fast staining (1%) due to the presence of mycolic acid in the cell wall. Unlike mycobacteria (also acid-fast positive), Nocardia has a FILAMENTOUS, ELONGATED, BRANCHING appearance on acid-fast staining .

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Silver staining is an excellent technique for detecting proteins which are separated by sodium dodecyl sulphate-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis Option: B. Albert's staining technique is chiefly used to demonstrate metachromatic granules found in Corynebacterium diphtheriae. Option: C. Periodic acid–Schiff (PAS) is a staining method used to detect polysaccharides such as glycogen, and mucosubstances such as glycoproteins, glycolipids and mucins in tissues

questions.text: Peripheral blood smear in a patient presenting with fever, headache and malaise showed rickettsial morulae in GRANULOCYTES. Which of the following is the likely cause of the symptoms in the patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Anaplasma Phagocytophilum Anaplasma phagocytophilum is an obligate gram-negative, intracellular bacterium that causes an acute febrile illness known as anaplasmosis or human granulocytic anaplasmosis (HGA)

Highyeild:

Ixodes ticks transmit Anaplasma phagocytophilum Diagnosed by culture, histopathology, PCR, or serology : The presence of intracytoplasmic aggregates of Anaplasma in peripheral blood neutrophils can be diagnostic in 20% to 80% of symptomatic patients. First-line treatment is doxycycline 100 mg orally, twice daily administered for 14 to 21 days Infection by both Anaplasma and Ehrlichia can lead to the formation of rickettsial morulae in leukocytes. However, Anaplasma leads to the formation of morula predominantly in the granulocytes, whereas Ehrlichia chaffeensis predominantly affects the monocytes . Ehrlichia chaffeensis is a gram-negative, obligate intracellular bacterium that is transmitted by hard ticks Clinical presentation of Ehrlichia chaffeensis infection is similar to that of Anaplasma infection. Severe human monocytic ehrlichiosis is characterised by meningoencephalitis, renal failure, respiratory failure, and shock. The treatment of choice for human monocytic ehrlichiosis is doxycycline.

questions.text: Acid fast stain of a specimen showed the following microscopic appearance. Which of the following is the likely organism seen in the specimen?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Nocardia Brasiliensis The image showing filamentous, branching acid-fast rods is suggestive of Nocardia. Nocardia appears as filamentous organisms with extensive hyphae-like branching. They are gram-positive, catalase-positive, and produce urease. They are weakly acid-fast (1% acid fast)

Highyeild:

Acid-fast structures Very few structures are acid-fast; this makes staining for acid-fastness particularly useful in diagnosis. The following are notable examples of structures which are acid-fast or modified acid-fast: All Mycobacteria - M. tuberculosis, M. leprae, M. smegmatis and atypical Mycobacterium Actinomycetes (especially some aerobic ones) with Mycolic acid in their cell wall (note Streptomyces do NOT have); not to be confused with Actinomyces, which is a non-acid-fast genera of Actinomycetes Nocardia Rhodococcus Gordonia (Actinomycete) Tsukamurella Dietzia Head of sperm Bacterial spores[ Endospore Legionella micdadei Certain cellular inclusions e.g. Cytoplasmic inclusion bodies seen in Neurons in layer 5 of cerebral cortex neuronal ceroid lipofuscinosis (Batten disease). Nuclear inclusion bodies seen in Lead poisoning Bismuth poisoning. Oocysts of some coccidian parasites in faecal matter, such as: Cryptosporidium parvum Isospora belli Cyclospora cayetanensis. A few other parasites: Sarcocystis

questions.text: Petechial rash is associated with all the following except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Roseola Infantum Roseola infantum is caused by infection with human herpesvirus 6 (HHV-6), or, less frequently, by human herpesvirus 7 (HHV-7). Roseola infantum, also known as exanthema subitum or sixth disease, typically presents in children between six and 12 months of age Patients with the virus classically present with acute onset high-grade fever up to 40 degrees celsius (104 degrees fahrenheit) lasting between three and five days. After that, rapid defervescence of the fever is accompanied by a nonpruritic, pink papular rash that begins on the trunk. Clinically diagnosed, self-limited illness that can be treated symptomatically The causative agents of Zika, Kyasanur Forest disease, and West Nile fever belong to the Flaviviridae group of viruses, which are known to cause hemorrhagic fever and present with petechial rashes.

questions.text: Transmission of which of the following viral Disease has been reported in India -
questions.explanation:
Solution:

West Nile Fever West Nile virus is a flavivirus that is transmitted by Culex mosquitoes . It can be subclinical or may present as a mild influenza-like illness. Encephalitis occurs in severe forms. Reverse-transcriptase PC has been used to identify the virus Hendra virus is endemic to Australia , and mostly affects horses. Ebola virus belongs to the genus Filovirus. It causes hemorrhagic fever. It is endemic to Africa . Yellow feve r is mostly confined to South and Central America , and certain parts of Africa. It is caused by flavivirus. It is an arthropod-borne hemorrhagic fever. Aedes aegypti transmits the disease.
